dt: {bc}the action or an instance of legally dissolving {dx_def}see {dxt|dissolve:1||1d}{/dx_def} a marriage

dt.t: {wi}divorce{/wi} of the secular and the spiritual

et: Middle English {it}divorse{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}divortium{/it}, from {it}divertere, divortere{/it} to divert, to leave one's husband
shortdef: the action or an instance of legally dissolving a marriage

dt: {bc}to legally dissolve one's marriage with {bc}to end marriage with (one's spouse) by divorce {dx_def}see {dxt|divorce:1||1}{/dx_def}

pt: {sc}separate{/sc} {sc}part{/sc} {sc}divide{/sc} {sc}sever{/sc} {sc}sunder{/sc} {sc}divorce{/sc} mean to become or cause to become disunited or disjointed. {sc}separate{/sc} may imply any of several causes such as dispersion, removal of one from others, or presence of an intervening thing.

pt.t: {it}separated{/it} her personal life from her career

pt: {sc}part{/sc} implies the separating of things or persons in close union or association.
{sc}divide{/sc} implies separating into pieces or sections by cutting or breaking.
{sc}sever{/sc} implies violence especially in the removal of a part or member.
{sc}sunder{/sc} suggests violent rending or wrenching apart.
{sc}divorce{/sc} implies separating two things that commonly interact and belong together.

pt.t: cannot {it}divorce{/it} scientific research from moral responsibility

shortdef: to legally dissolve one's marriage with : to end marriage with (one's spouse) by divorce
to dissolve the marriage contract between
to make or keep separate : separate
